There are various challenges that arise when trying to document and preserve endangered languages. Here are some of the main ones:

1. Limited resources: Efforts to document and preserve endangered languages often require significant resources in terms of time, funding, and expertise. Many language communities or researchers may not have access to these resources, which can hinder their efforts.

2. Lack of written materials: Many endangered languages have limited or no written materials, which makes it more challenging to document and preserve them.

3. Social and cultural factors: Some communities may view their language as being of low status or may not see any immediate benefit in preserving it. There may also be socio-cultural barriers that make it difficult to access certain language communities.

4. Language attrition: Endangered languages may have few or no native speakers, and the remaining speakers may not have full command of the language. This can result in language attrition, meaning that the language is gradually lost over time.

5. Cultural misappropriation: Some languages may have cultural practices or beliefs attached to them, and these may be sensitive or sacred. It is important to work closely with the language communities to ensure that their languages and cultures are not misappropriated or exploited in any way.

There may also be unique challenges that are specific to certain languages or communities. For example, some languages may have a complex grammar or may be difficult to transcribe, which can make documentation and preservation more challenging. It is essential to work closely with each community to understand their unique needs and challenges, and to tailor preservation efforts accordingly.
